A type of temperament caused by the predominance of Dam (sanguine) in the body. It is hot and moist. The individuals with this type of temperament have strong built, full pulse, pinkish colour of skin, etc.

A type of temperament caused by the predominance of Balgham (phlegm) in the body. It is cold and moist. The individuals with this type of temperament have fatty body, excessive sleep, whitish colour of skin, etc.

A type of temperament caused by the predominance of Ṣafrā’ (yellow bile) in the body. It is hot and dry. The individuals with this type of temperament have thin built, yellowish colour of the skin, rapid pulse, etc.

A type of temperament caused by the predominance of Sawdā’ (black bile) in the body. It is cold and dry. The individuals with this type of temperament have thin built with prominent veins, blackish color of the skin, etc.

sanguine humour, devoid of  its normal qualities either through change of temperament such as getting hot or cold or due to admixture with the humours derived from outside or produced within the sanguine humour, e.g., when a part of it gets putrefied, the lighter portion is converted into abnormal yellow bile and the heavier portion into abnormal black bile
phlegm devoid of basic characters of normal phlegm
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, which is saline or alkaline in taste and inclined towards heat and dryness
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, which is sour in taste and inclined towards coldness and dryness
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, which is tasteless, very immature and quite cold
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, which is gallic in taste and inclined towards coldness and dryness
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, which is sweet in taste and inclined towards heat and moistness
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, having  watery consistency
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, having extremely thick consistency
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, having mucoid consistency
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, having vitreous consistency
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, having foul smell, produced by sepsis/infection/putrefaction
yellow bile that becomes abnormal either due to addition of  extraneous material or alteration in its own composition
one of the abnormal types of yellow bile, produced by the admixture of thick phlegm
one of the abnormal types of yellow bile, produced by the admixture of thin phlegm
one of the abnormal types of yellow bile, produced by the admixture of burnt black bile

one of the abnormal types of yellow bile, produced by the combustion of ordinary yellow bile, resulting in development of leek green colour due to mixing of the burnt material  with the original yellow bile
the hottest and the most lethal of all abnormal types of yellow bile produced due to extreme combustion of leek green bile
black bile produced either by the combustion of black bile itself or combustion of any of the other three humours, i.e., sanguine, phlegm, yellow bile
one of the abnormal types of black bile, produced by the combustion  of sanguine
one of the abnormal types of black bile, produced by the combustion  of yellow bile
one of the abnormal types of black bile, produced by the combustion  of phlegm
one of the abnormal types of black bile, produced by the combustion  of black bile itself
single disease  is produced either due to the abnormality of temperament or composition or breach in continuity
temperament wherein the qualities and quantities of all the participating primary components in a compound are not in accordance with the natural needs

Arabic_term: مزاج غیر معتدل مفرد/سوء مزاج مفرد
Definition: imbalance of  temperament occurring due to dominance of any one of the four qualities, i.e., heat, cold, dryness, moistness, on the other three qualities

Arabic_term: سوء مزاج مفرد سادہ/مزاج غیر معتدل مفرد سادہ
NUMC_TERM: Sū’-i-Mizāj Mufrad Sāda/Mizāj Ghayr Mu‘tadil Mufrad Sāda
Definition: when derangement of temperament is without any substance
when the heat dominates abnormally in the body
when the cold dominates abnormally in the body
when the wetness dominates abnormally in the body
when dryness dominates abnormally in the body
a simple abnormal temperament which is associated with the substance
abnormal hot temperament caused by the predominance of hot substance
abnormal cold temperament caused by the predominance of cold substance
abnormal wet temperament caused by the predominance of wet substance
abnormal wet temperament caused by the predominance of dry substance

Arabic_term: مزاج غیر معتدل مرکب/سوء مزاج مرکب
Definition: imbalance of  temperament occurring due to dominance of any two of the four qualities, i.e., heat, cold, dryness, moistness

Arabic_term: سوء مزاج مرکب سادہ/مزاج غیر معتدل مرکب سادہ
NUMC_TERM: Sū’-i-Mizāj Murakkab Sāda/Mizāj Ghayr Mu‘tadil Murakkab Sāda
Definition: the compound abnormal temperament which occurs when any two (one active and one passive) of the four physical properties i.e. hotness, coldness, dryness and wetness/moistness dominate abnormally on the other without involving the substance
abnormal predominance of hot and wet temperament without involving the substance
abnormal hot and dry temperament caused by only predominance of hot and dry temperament without involving the substance
abnormal cold and wet temperament caused by only predominance of cold and wet temperament without involving the substance
abnormal cold and dry temperament caused by only predominance of cold and dry temperament without involving the substance

compound abnormal temperament which occurs when any two (one active and one passive) of the four physical properties i.e. hot, cold, dry and moist dominate abnormally on the other due to predominance of substance
abnormal hot and wet temperament associated with predominance of hot and wet substances
abnormal hot and dry temperament associated with predominance of hot and dry substances
abnormal cold and wet  temperament associated with predominance of cold and wet substances
abnormal cold and dry temperament associated with predominance of cold and dry substances
the temperament which comes into being when any one of the four physical properties i.e. hotness, coldness, dryness and wetness/moistness dominates abnormally on the other three
abnormal temperament wherein the change in four qualities, i.e.,  hotness, coldness, dryness and wetness/moistness is associated with increase/decrease of substance (humour)
abnormal temperament, which continues in a steady mode and does not get corrected easily
abnormal temperament, which does not continue in a steady mode and gets corrected easily
diseases of abnormal composition
diseases in which original shape of the organ is changed
one of the types of diseases of constitution involving particularly the morphological alterations in the compound organs
one of the types of diseases of constitution specific to tracts/ tubular structures such as vessels, ducts etc. In these conditions the lumen may get dilated, narrowed or completely blocked
dilatation of tracts/ ducts
narrowing of tracts/ ducts
obstruction of tracts/ ducts
one of the types of diseases of constitution seen in hollow organs leading to either abnormal narrowing or dilatations. It includes increase, decrease, occlusion or emptiness
dilatation of vasa/cavity
narrowing of vasa/cavity
vasa/ cavity getting obstructed or repleted, e.g. obstruction of ventricles of brain in apoplexy
depletion of vasa/cavity

one of the types of diseases of constitution associated with the alterations in surface  of viscera/organ causing compromised physiological functions e.g. a viscera originally having smooth surface becomes rough/puckered and vice versa
roughness of the surface which should be smooth, e.g. roughness of internal surface of trachea
smoothness of the surface which should be rough, e.g. smoothness of internal surface of stomach
one of the types of diseases of constitution that deal with the pathological changes in size / weight of body viscera/organs. All kind of hypertrophies or atrophies come under this category
increase in the size, e.g. elephantiasis
generalized/ as a whole increase in the size, e.g. obesity
localized increase in the size/increase in the size of part/organ of the body, e.g. hepatomegaly, splenomegaly etc.
decrease in the size of the organs
generalized/ as a whole decrease in the size, e.g. emaciation
localized decrease in the size/ decrease in the size of part of the body, e.g. shrinkage of the size of the eyeball or tongue
one of the types of diseases of constitution which is associated with the congenital or acquired numeral abnormality of viscera or body organs
increase in number of the body parts, like appearance of extra teeth and fingers
congenital increase in number of parts of the body, e.g. additional teeth or additional finger
acquired pathological increase in the parts of the body, e.g. tumour
decrease in number of the body parts, e.g. presence of one kidney instead of two
congenital decrease in number of body parts, e.g. congenital absence of one finger
acquired decrease in number of parts of the body, e.g. accidental loss of one finger

one of the types of diseases of constitution in which defects in position and proximity of body organs occur. The defects in position include total or partial shifting of any organ. It also includes the defects in voluntary and involuntary movements of body organs. The movement may decrease or increase. The defects in proximity include, loss of gap between two adjacent organs leading to cessation of their movement

there are four types of diseases related to the position: 1. total shifting of the organ from its position, 2. partial shifting of the organ like in hernia, 3. involuntary abnormal increased movement of an organ like in tremors and 4. decreased movement of a movable organ like stiffness of joint
complete displacement of body part, like displacement of joint. When the head of the bone completely subluxate from its normal position
incomplete displacement or displacement of part of an organ, like intestinal hernia
abnormal (sometimes involuntary) movement of an organ, like tremors
fixity of an organ to its location, like calcification of joints in gout
the disease of an organ that arises due to its association with another organ
restriction of movement of an organ, which was movable
painful movement or difficult movement
loss of continuity of any organ or part of the body
loss of continuity of skin caused by sharp pointed object
loss of continuity of skin due to excoriation/ scraping
loss of continuity of bone in such a way that it breaks into pieces
longitudinal loss of continuity of bone
longitudinal minimal loss of continuity of nerve
longitudinal loss of continuity of muscle
transverse loss of continuity of nerve
loss of continuity of muscle at its end
transverse loss of continuity of muscle
loss of continuity of vein
sudden break in the continuity of a body part
when any humour exceeds the normal quantity
the diseases which arise due to the abnormal quantity or quality of the sanguine humour. These diseases are considered to be of hot and moist temperament
the diseases which arise due to the abnormal quantity or quality of the bilious humour. These diseases are considered to be of hot and dry temperament
the diseases which arise due to the abnormal quantity or quality of the phlegmatic humour. These diseases are considered to be of cold and moist temperament
the diseases which arise due to the abnormal quantity or quality of the melancholic humour. These diseases are considered to be of cold and moist temperament
pulse, the parts of which are perceived to be greater in length when compared with absolutely normal pulse
pulse, the parts of which are perceived to be shorter in length when compared with absolutely normal pulse
pulse, the parts of which are perceived to be broader in breadth when compared with absolutely normal pulse
pulse, the parts of which are perceived to be narrower in breadth when compared with absolutely normal pulse
pulse, the parts of which are perceived to be more elevated in height when compared with absolutely normal pulse
pulse, the parts of which are perceived to be less elevated in height when compared with absolutely normal pulse
pulse increased both in length and breadth as well as in elevation
pulse diminished both in length and breadth as well as in elevation
pulse increased both in breadth and height
pulse decreased both in breadth and height
pulse, which resists the fingers of physician during palpation
pulse which does not resist the fingers of physician during palpation
pulse whose movement is completed in a short space of time
pulse whose movement is completed in a long space of time
pulse having small pause between two beats
pulse having long duration of pause between two beats
easily compressible pulse
firm and incompressible pulse
pulse which seems to be full of blood
pulse which seems to be empty
pulse having higher temperature
pulse having lower degree of temperature
pulse equal in its five features, i.e., largeness and smallness, strength and weakness, swiftness and sluggishness, rapidness and slowness and hardness and softness
pulse equal in largeness and smallness, strength and weakness, swiftness and sluggishness, rapidness and slowness and hardness and softness
pulse which is equal in any one of its five  features, i.e., largeness and smallness, strength and weakness, swiftness and sluggishness, rapidness and slowness and hardness and softness
pulse unequal in  its five features, i.e., largeness and smallness, strength and weakness, swiftness and sluggishness, rapidness and slowness and hardness and softness
pulse unequal in largeness and smallness, strength and weakness, swiftness and sluggishness, rapidness and slowness and hardness and softness
pulse unequal in any one of its five  features, i.e., largeness and smallness, strength and weakness, swiftness and sluggishness, rapidness and slowness and hardness and softness
variation of a pulse-beat felt only under one finger, which is marked by faint interruption
an abnormal condition of pulse in which a large pulse becomes small and returns to the original height in a gradual manner
pulse in which the increase or decrease in any feature appears in such a gradual manner that the change can not be perceived
pulse, which varies according to a definite order
pulse in which only one irregularity is repeated
pulse, in which two or more irregularities go on repeating in cycles
pulse, which does not vary according to a definite order
pulse having rhythm in accordance with the age of person
pulse having rhythm which is not in  accordance with the age of person
pulse, which acquires the rhythm of the pulse of person belonging to adjacent age group, e.g., rhythm of a child’s pulse becomes that of the pulse of a young man
pulse, which acquires the rhythm of the pulse of person not belonging to adjacent age group, e.g., rhythm of a child’s pulse corresponds to that of an old man’s pulse
pulse whose rhythm does not match any age
pulse, irregular in two or more features
compound pulse, which starts from smallness, increases up to a certain limit, starts declining and comes back to the original position
compound pulse, in which pause occurs where the movement is expected
compound pulse, in which an extra beat appears during the period of rest after the first beat has ended
compound pulse, which is considered to be single beat by some physicians and coupled beat by others
compound pulse which gradually increases or decreases in one or more features of the beats
mouse tail pulse, which is irregular in the expansion of the beat and starts as large pulse but does not end on a definite limit of smallness
mouse tail pulse, which starts as large pulse and ends as small pulse
mouse tail pulse, which starts as large pulse and ends as small pulse thereafter rebounds to the state of large pulse
compound pulse which has its beats sluggish in initial phase but later on it suddenly becomes quick
slow rising pulse
compound pulse similar to wavy pulse but is small and rapid
compound pulse smaller and more rapid than the vermicular pulse. In this kind of pulse height and length are more affected than the width in comparison of vermicular pulse
compound pulse resembling wavy pulse but firm and hard in nature
compound pulse, in which there are repeated jerky movements similar to spasm
compound pulse, which is feeble and trembling
compound pulse which seems similar to thread being twisted
compound pulse which is a variety of  twisting pulse but resembles the tremulous pulse
urine, which indicates some degree of heat in comparison of normal urine
colour of urine that resembles with the peel of orange but the red colour is more prominent as compared to reddish-yellow urine and indicates higher degree of heat
colour of urine that  resembles with the saffron-soaked water and indicates higher degree of heat in comparison of orange-yellow coloured urine
colour of urine that  resembles with the filaments of saffron and indicates higher degree of heat in comparison of reddish-yellow, orange-yellow and flame-yellow urine
urine indicating predominance of sanguine in the body
urine indicating predominance of sanguine in the body
urine indicating predominance of sanguine in the body
urine indicating predominance of sanguine in the body
yellow-coloured urine mixed with little bit of black colour, which indicates predominance of cold in the body
urine, which indicates the extreme combustion within the body
urine, which indicates extremely cold morbid temperament
urine, which indicates cold morbid temperament
urine, which indicates extreme combustion within the body but is less risky than verdigris-green urine
urine, which denotes extreme combustion of humours, extreme cold, extinction of the innate heat and evacuation of melancholic wastes by the medicatrix naturae after crisis
a type of urine, which may  be transparent or translucent
white-coloured transparent urine, which denotes coldness of temperament and defective maturation
white-coloured urine which resembles milk and is viscous in nature
urine that denotes the excess of immature phlegm
urine that contains emulsified fat derived from tissues
urine that contains phlegm from the actual or threatened dissolution of tissues
urine when mixed with pus indicates the ulceration of urinary tract and without pus indicates the presence of partially matured phlegm or stone in the bladder
urine that passes during crisis of phlegmatic swellings, in case where the tissues are loose and in the diseases caused by vitreous phlegm
urine, which is a grave sign when passes without sediment
urine, which is a fatal sign when passed in the course of an acute fever
urine, which denotes weakness of liver or excess of blood
clear, viscid and moderately dense urine, in which the yellow colour is tinged with oily translucence. It gives an oily sheen and indicates bad prognosis
urine that points towards fatal prognosis as it is an indication of the combustion of yellow and black bile
urine in which red colour is tinged with the black colour and is a sign of any complicated fever or fever occurring due to thick humour
urine which generally shows that maturation is incomplete and sometimes indicates towards obstruction in the blood vessels or weakness of kidneys
urine which generally shows defective maturation  and sometimes indicates towards elimination of thick mature humours
urine indicative of cold morbid temperament, excessive rawness and extinction of innate heat in case of acute diseases
urine indicative of predominance of yellow bile. Foul sour smelling urine is indicative of predominance of black bile
froth of urine, which denotes jaundice
froth of urine, which denotes jaundice
smallness of urine bubbles
urine bubbles, which denote viscidity of matter
lack of urine bubbles
abundance of urine bubbles which denotes viscidity of matter and presence of gas
bursting of urine bubbles in a slow manner which indicates viscidity of matter and presence of gas
rapid bursting of urine bubbles
large red or large white sediments, usually coming from the organs of urinary system. White flaky sediments come from the bladder and red or fleshy flaky sediments come from the kidney
small and thick scales denoting bladder disorder or wasting of organs
reddish small and thick scales denoting the destruction of liver substance or combustion of blood. Occasionally they come from kidneys
scales which are produced due to burning of blood
scales when reddish denote burning of blood. Dark scales show excessive destruction of blood
flat and large white or red scales which generally arise from the immediate urinary organs, e.g., kidneys, bladder
sediments, which arise from kidneys or from the breakdown of tissues in the body
sediments, which generally denote dissolution of solid and liquid fat as well as flesh
sediments, which denote discharge of pus from ulcers of urinary organs
sediments, which generally denote presence of large quantity of thick immature humour in the body
sediments, which denote weakness of stomach and intestine and impairment of digestion
sediments, which generally denote weakness of liver when found in large quantity and ulceration or injury of the urinary tract when found in small quantity
sediments, which indicate that active heat has coagulated the elongated exudates and converted them into fibrils
sediments, which indicate stone formation or stone disintegration
sediments, which denote the change in the colour of pus or mucus due to their prolonged stagnation
a term denoting the abundance of sediments in urine due to excess of causative agent
a term denoting the scantiness of sediments in urine due to lack of causative agent
sediments, which denote excessive burning of blood, excessive cold or failure of innate heat
sediments, which denote the predominance of sanguine or impaired digestion
sediments, which denote the presence of strong heat or insidious disease
sediments, which indicate the appearance of dark coloured sediments in urine
sediments, which may be normal or abnormal (purulent, mucoid and gummy denoting deficient maturation)
quantity of stool, which denotes presence of excessive humours in the body
quantity of stool, which denotes the presence of low quantity of humours in the body or the retention of much of stool in the caecum, colon and small intestine
consistency of stool, which denotes indigestion, obstructions, weakness of the mesentery and catarrhal secretions coming from head
consistency of stool, which denotes  fatigue, excessive urination, presence of excessive heat in the body, use of dry foods and constipation
colour of stool, which denotes excess of yellow bile in the body
colour of stool, which denotes obstruction in the bile duct and jaundice
colour of stool, which denotes excessive combustion, maturation of causative matter of melancholic diseases or intake of any coloured diet
colour of stool, which denotes extinction of the innate heat
shape of stool, which denotes flatulence
passing out of stool before the usual time, which denotes the excess of bile in gall bladder and weakness of retentive faculty
delay in the passage of stools, which denotes weakness of digestion, coldness of intestines and excess of moisture
sputum that denotes predominance of yellow bile and severity of heat
sputum that denotes predominance of sanguine
sputum that denotes predominance of sanguine and heat
sputum that denotes coldness, immaturity and heat
sputum that denotes the combustion and bad quality of disease causing matter
sputum, which denotes that the disease causing matter is still in an immature state
sputum denoting the thickness of disease causing matter
sputum denoting the severity of putrefaction
sputum denoting good prognosis
profuse expectoration, which denotes the maturity of disease causing matter and stationary phase of disease
scanty expectoration, which denotes the progressive phase of disease
moderate expectoration, which denotes the convalescence
sweat that denotes predominance of yellow bile in the body
sweat that denotes predominance of sanguine in the body
sweat that denotes predominance of black bile in the body
sweat that denotes predominance of black bile in the body
sweat that denotes predominance of black bile in the body
sweat that denotes healthy condition of  the body
condition that denotes weakness and decreased vitality
condition that denotes the weakness of repulsive faculty
condition that denotes severity of putrefaction and heat
condition that denotes presence of bilious, pungent and sharp matter
sweat that denotes sour phlegm
condition that denotes the thinness of disease causing matter
condition that denotes the thickness of disease causing matter
loss of senses
weak body

one of the four groups of causes of health and disease whose immediate subject is the organs and their pneuma, the more remote subject is the humours and the most remote subject is the primary components

one of the four groups of causes of health and disease which either preserves or produces changes in the human body and are: (a) various types of airs and associated factors; (b) food, water and other drinks, etc.; (c) evacuation and retention; (d) habitat and residence, etc.; (e) physiological and psychological rest and activity; (f) sleep and wakefulness; (g) various phases of life and variations therein; (h) sex variations; (i) occupations; (j) habits; and (k) favourable and unfavourable agents  affecting the human body by contact
one of the four groups of causes of health and disease  which includes temperaments, faculties emerging from these temperaments and structures
one of the four groups of causes of health and diseases, which includes functions
the causes which are common to many diseases
causes which are specifically responsible for creating pathological lesion/ disease
causes related to body itself
two causes occur at the same time for a disease and absence of either of these result in the end of the disease. e.g. sepsis in fevers
causes that befall the body from within (repletion, starvation)
non-corporeal (out side the body) causes which produce corporeal states directly e.g. blow, atmospheric heat, hot or cold food or psychological factors like anger or fear
essential causes  usually intrinsic in nature
the causes that are dependant on other causes
the causes when abolished, their effects persist
the causes when abolished, their effects disappear
the causes which are not basic in nature but arise out of certain basic causes
the causes that distort the shape of the organ
the causes that are responsible for obstruction, it may be inflammation/swelling of the tract or presence of any foreign body
the causes that are responsible for narrowing of the tract, it may be inflammation/ swelling of the tract or presence of any foreign body
the causes that are responsible for dilatation of the tract may be weakening of the circular constricting fibres, increased eliminating power or drugs that dilate the tract temporarily
the causes that are responsible for roughness of the surface include the use of detergent, resolvent, dry or cold medicines, etc.

the causes that are responsible for smoothness of the surface of the skin or mucous membrane include the use of demulcent substance, mild resolvent medicine, mild hot medicine that normalizes the coldness of the surface

the causes that are responsible for dislocation or displacement of the organs, includie increased tension/ pressure in the joint, rigorous movement or any condition that loosens the joint/ muscle etc.
the causes that are responsible for abnormal association such as stiffness, spasm, flaccidity of the adjacent organ or foreign body affecting the organ in contact
the causes that are responsible for abnormal movement of an organ such as weakness, dryness, spasm or collection of morbid material in the organ
the causes responsible for increase in size include increased quantity of material due to increased absorption in the organ
the causes responsible for increase in number which is usually due to malformation
the causes that are responsible for decrease in  size of organ due to malformation, accidental loss or decaying by infection etc.
the causes that are responsible for decrease in number of organ may be malformation, accidental loss or decaying by infection
factors modifying the state of human body

causes of loss of continuity of organ include internal causes like, corrosive humour (as caseation and loss of tissue in leprosy) or excessive abnormal humour (accumulated in joints in arthritis) or may be due to external causes, that may include injury by sharp object, too hot object or heavy object etc.
causes of ulcer formation  may be bursting of inflammatory mass, pustule or abscess, pus formation in an injury, etc.

causes of inflammation may be strong expulsive power of adjacent organ and weak retentive power of the affected organ. The causes of inflammation of organ may vary depending upon nature of the organ, texture of the organ, width of the passage or orifice which may be too narrow or too wide related to the organ, low position of outlet and small outlet, and increased heat in particular regions
causes of pain include sudden and temporary change in temperament or loss of continuity
causes that relieve the pain, include the removal of the cause of pain or increase in the moistness, inducing sleep, use of soothing and analgesic agents
causes of pleasure including sudden restoration of abnormal temperament and restoration of loss of continuity

weak expulsive faculty, strong retentive faculty which may result due to weakness of digestive faculty,  narrowing  and obstruction of passages and thickness, viscidity and increased amount of waste material

strong expulsive faculty, weak retentive faculty, matters causing injury by its excess quantity which produces heaviness, gaseous substances, distension, corrosive and acrid matters, dilution of matters and extended passage

these include weakness of digestive faculty, weak evacuation power, strong retentive power, narrowing of ducts and channels, Ḥammām (Turkish bath/bath) after meal,  excess of repose and lack of exercise and movement

causes of weakness of organs may include persistent abnormal temperament especially cold abnormal temperament, weakness of texture of the organ especially of nerves, weakness of different faculties and presence of compound disease etc.

factors of life including air, foods and drinks,  bodily movement and repose, mental activity and repose, sleep and wakefulness,  retention and evacuation which are essential for every living human being; and an imbalance in these factors lead to various disease conditions
treatment of diseases by manipulating and maintaining the dietary pattern depending upon the requirement of treatment of diseases
complete abstinence from the intake of food temporarily to facilitate the evacuation of morbid matter from the body commonly in the treatment of acute illnesses
reducing/ lessening the intake of diet in order to conserve the power of digestive faculty
reducing/ lessening the quantity of dietary intake but maintaining the nutritional requirement of the body
the quantity of diet in terms of nutritional value is reduced which decreases the production of humours and provides favourable medium for concoction of morbid matters

Arabic_term: تقلیل غذا ءبہ اعتبار کمیت و کیفیت
Definition: the diet both in terms of quality and quantity is reduced particularly when faculties of body are not markedly disturbed
it is the treatment of disease with the help of medicines/ drugs
treatment of disease with single medicines e.g. herbal, mineral or animal origin
treatment of disease with compound drugs/ formulations e.g. tablets, syrups, powders and other semisolid dosage forms

one of the basic principles of treatment in Unani system of medicine in which the physician chooses the drugs, diets or any other mode of treatment having qualities opposite to the quality/temperament of the disease
treatment of patients with psychiatric/spiritual measures
principle of treatment of correction of an abnormal temperament that leads to morbidity
a process by which the morbid material matures and is made evacuable out of body. The drugs for Nuḍj(concoction) or the duration of Nuḍj(concoction) is specific to humoral morbidity
the process by which the humours mature and is made evacuable from the body
the process by which the phlegm humour matures and is made evacuable from the body
the process by which yellow bile matures and is made evacuable from the body
the process by which Black bile matures and is made evacuable from the body
induced evacuation of morbid matter/ humours from the body
induced elimination of morbid material from the body, usually done after proper concoction
elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the brain
elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the head
elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the chest
elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the teeth
elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the stomach
elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the liver
elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the spleen
elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the intestine
elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the kidney
elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the urinary passage
principle of treatment of removal of pus from ulcers through drugs
elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the body of lactating mother
diversion of morbid matter/ humour from the affected site to another site or increase in the flow of humours towards a specific site
diversion of morbid humours from the affected site towards the adjacent organs or parts of the body
diversion of morbid matter/ humour from the affected site towards a distant organ or part of the body
the process to induce pain by any means like pressing or tying the organ or cupping of the organ, etc. performed to divert the morbid matter
to shift the morbid material from diseased part to distant non vital part
to bring morbid materials at normal/balanced condition
moderation of consistency
to bring blood at normal consistency
the process to bring yellow bile to its normal condition
moderation of temperament or bringing the abnormal temperament to the normal temperament
alteration of the temperament
removal of the cause of the disease or treatment of the cause
to stop the infiltration or effusion of the humours from one organ to another
a method of treatment in which the heat is produced/ generated within the body by drugs or regimens
a method of treatment in which the heat is produced/ generated within the body by drugs or regimens
producing heat in the brain
producing heat in the head
producing heat in the heart
producing heat in the stomach
producing heat in the cardiac end of the stomach
producing heat in the liver
producing heat in the intestine
producing heat in the kidney
producing heat in the urinary bladder
producing heat in the uterus
producing heat in the semen producing organs
principle of treatment in which extremities are warmed through various means to divert the disease causing matter from the affected organs towards them
principle of treatment advocated in case of cold morbid temperament
a method of treatment in which coldness is produced/ generated or heat is reduced within the body by drugs or regimen
a method of treatment in which the cold is produced/ generated within the body by drugs or regimens
producing cold in the brain
producing cold in the head
producing cold in the stomach
producing cold in the cardiac end of stomach
producing cold in the liver
producing cold in the spleen
producing cold in the testes
principle of treatment advocated in case of hot morbid temperament
the process of moistening of the body or the part of the body by drugs or regimen
a method of treatment in which the moistness is produced/ generated within the body by drugs or regimens
producing moistness in the brain
producing moistness in the head
producing moistness in the throat
producing moistness in the liver
producing moisture in the room of patient
the process of reducing the increased heat of the humours and organs
removing the vapours accumulated in an organ or body part
the process of producing dryness in the body or the part of the body
producing dryness in the brain
producing dryness in the stomach
producing dryness in the liver
the process of producing dryness through absorption of fluids and other material from the body especially towards intestine as in case of Ishāl (purgation) by the action of drugs
the act of refining of any thick viscid matter
the process of resolving the inflammation
the process of softening the inflammation of hard organ/ inflammation associated with black bile
to induce rupture of an abscess through local application of drugs/regimen
the process of dilatation of the blood vessels either by using drugs having hot and wet temperament or by drugs that dissolve the thick substance blocking  the vessels
removing obstructions from ducts
removing obstructions from bile canaliculi
removing obstructions from urinary tract
opening the skin pores
constricting the skin pores
the process to remove any obstruction by using deobstruents
elimination of anything which is an addition in quantity or quality to the physiological composition of blood and considered as an impurity, by drug or any regimen
cut out the morbid material to make it easily evacuable
attenuation/thinning of the morbid matter
making the disease causing matter dilute
attracting the morbid matter from the affected site to another site. It is one of the objectives of Imāla
making the thin morbid matter thick to facilitate its evacuation and prevent from absorption in other organs
the process of lubricating the surface of organ, e.g.,  intestine
the process that repels the morbid material from affected part
the process which expels the flatus from the gastrointestinal tract
relaxing the muscles which commonly results in pain reduction
the process which stimulates the nerves
process which stimulation the functioning of brain
invigorating the innate heat
the process of toning up to enhance the functions and maintain the health of the human body by stimulating the metabolism, strengthening the internal organs and improving the body functions
the process that strengthens the vital organs i.e.. heart, brain and liver
the process that strengthens the brain
the process which provides strength to the nerves
the process which improves the eyesight
the process which binds the gums and strengthens the teeth
the process which tones up the heart and improves its function
the process which tones up the liver and improves its function
the process which strengthens the kidney and improves its function
the process which strengthens the bladder and improves its function
the process which strengthens the genitals and improves its function
the process which strengthens the uterus and improves its function
the process which strengthens the skin to grow hair
strengthening of head
improving the eye sight
strengthening of teeth
strengthening of roots of teeth
strengthening of stomach
strengthening of cardiac end stomach
strengthening the innate heat
transforming the morbid humour into moderate consistency
disintegrating the morbid material into smaller particles
transforming the body humours into moderate consistency
advising the diets which produce blood of thin consistency
advising measures, e.g., food, drink, exercise which are light in nature and produce freshness
invigorating psychic pneuma
dispersion of disease causing matter accumulated in an organ or body part
resolving the gases accumulated in an organ or body part
dispersion of vapours accumulated in an organ or body part
the process which increases the circulation of blood of the skin and helps in growing of the hair
a method of treatment in which the whole body or a part of it is reversibly anaesthetized through drugs
to induce sleep with the help of the drugs or regimens
the term is used for (1) relieving any type of pain; (2) producing soothing effect in any local lesion; (3) causing anti diarrhoeal effect by reducing the peristaltic movement
cooling of disease causing matter
cooling the increased heat of the body
alleviating the vapours arising from any organ
the process that reduces the irritability or excitement of brain
the process of reducing abnormally increased  function of heart
cooling of humours
to relieve the pain by using drugs, changing temperament of the pain site or by some other means
stasis of blood
the process of reducing perspiration/ sweating, required when there is excessive sweating
the process to induce blister formation by hot fluid or by some drugs to increase the blood supply of a particular organ e.g. liniments used in male sexual debility
cleaning of the infected wound with some drugs like blue vitriol
promotion of wound healing by the use of desiccant drugs
decreasing the libido
boosting the libido

to increase the secretion of milk

the process of crushing the stone (usually renal/ureteric/vesicular), by some drugs/regimens

the process to expel out the intestinal worms by drugs called vermifuge
expulsion of foetus
reducing the production of breast milk
process to check or eradicate the infection
the process to reduce the temperature (of the body), usually achieved by sweating or application of some cooling agents like cold water or by some drugs etc.
reducing the quantity of disease causing matter
the process to induce sneezing
the process to shed the body weight or to reduce the bulk of any part of the body/organ
the process to increase the body weight or the bulk of any part of the body/organ
the process to soften the intestinal content or to evacuate the excrement from intestine
regimenal therapy is modification in six essential factors (AAsbāb Sitta Ḍarūriyya), for the maintenance of health as well as for the management of diseases
evacuation of matter from the body through intestines as a regimen
to induce the vomiting as a regimen to evacuate the gastric contents
to induce the increased flow of urine or menstruation as a regimen
the regimen/drugs by which sputum is expelled out/ expectorated from the lungs
blood letting through venesection is one of the mode of regimenal therapy for complete evacuation of morbid matter, leading to moderation of all humours

a mode of regimenal therapy which is used for diversion or evacuation of the morbid matter from the body. It may be  without scarification or with scarification (blood letting). Previously the animal horns had been used but now a days metal/ plastic cups and small suction pump are used on the body surface to create the vacuum through suction for the diversion or evacuation of morbid matter.
cupping therapy with scarification for blood letting to achieve local evacuation of morbid matter
cupping therapy without scarification, only application of cups with vacuum creation within it for diversion of morbid matter
dry cupping, where vacuum is created with fire  inside the cups
cupping therapy where vacuum is created without fire
cupping therapy along with warm water/ medicinal decoction while cupping
leech application as a regimen is one of the method of evacuation. It is specially useful at the site where venesection or hijamah is not done properly
sweating as a regimen is usually done to remove morbid matter through skin

turkish bath, which is constructed as per specific guidelines, where the temperature of different rooms are different for therapeutic purpose like cleansing, reducing the viscosity of matter and elimination and diversion of morbid matter

in this type of bath, the person is kept in a high temperature, thus stay in hot and dry room as well as in hot and wet room is prolonged. Beneficial for spasms, pain in liver and kidney, and pain in joints
in this type of bath medicated water is used
in this type of bath a little borax is mixed in the water
in this type of bath a little sulphur is mixed in the water. It is beneficial for different skin diseases etc.
in this type of bath part of the body or whole body up to neck is covered with sand. It is beneficial for ascites, arthritis, and frozen joints etc.
taking bath in sea water, different kind of salts in sea water is beneficial for skin
exposure to sunlight is often called sun bath. It is beneficial for different skin diseases and to tan the white skin
in this type of bath some oil or some drugs dissolved in olive oil is massaged over the body
in this type of bath the water is used in which some strong astringent like alum is dissolved
induced physical movement of the body as a regimen
the exercise, which is not intentionally done but carried out as a part of profession like that of work of blacksmith
exercise which is purely done for the purpose and intentionally in order to get benefits of exercise
exercise for a shorter duration, stopped soon after starting
exercise that is not stopped sooner but continued for a longer duration
extensive/ rigorous exercise, usually done forcefully. This may lead to hardening of the organs, but sometimes may lead to excessive evacuation and lethargy
light exercise, where much force is not used. It may be done by moving from one place to another etc.
rapid/ fast exercise, where movement is done rapidly at a fast pace
slow exercise, where movement is done at a slow pace
rigorous and rapid exercise
exercise which is done slowly and without much force
moderate exercise, where force as well as movement is moderate
regimen involving manual manipulation of muscles, leading to elimination of metabolic waste
strong and extensive pressure massage in order to harden an organ
soft handed light and gentle pressure massage done in order to open up the channels/ vessels leading to softening of the organ
massage for a shorter duration
massage for a longer duration
massage, moderate in terms of force as well as time leading to healthy organs
rough massage, usually done with any rough cloth, it increases peripheral blood circulation excessively
soft or smooth massage usually done with oil or soft cloth
the massage done before exercise as a preparatory measure
massage done after exercise, to relax the body/ organ and bring back to its normal condition
treatment of diseases through surgical procedures
procedure of burning the skin or flesh to stop bleeding or avoid further putrefaction with the help of heated instrument or caustic substance
procedure of cauterization with heated metals
procedure of cauterization with heated iron
procedure of cauterization with heated gold
procedure of cauterization with caustic substances
making of cut  into the body during surgical interventions
surgical intervention of the swellings
process of making incision over the abscess to drain the pus
rupture of a swellings
procedure of making a cut into the larynx under the third or the fourth ring of trachea
surgical procedure carried out to remove the  stone from urinary bladder
procedure involving amputation of limbs affected by gangrene
cutting a bone or piece from it
surgical procedure of removal of skin of prepuce
procedure of removal of twisted veins surgically
procedure to remove ascitic fluid
cutting or removal of the part of the body to control the disease process
art of the setting of the fracture or dislocation
procedure of reduction of dislocated joints of body
surgical procedure, which involves the stitching of the edges of wound with the help of sutures
maintenance of health and management of diseases through diets
dietary substance, which becomes part of the body and does not produce any qualitative change such as heat, cold, etc.
diet, used  without the addition of other substances
diet prepared by the combination of many other substances
dietary substance, which produces heat in the body
dietary substance, which produces cold in the body
dietary substance, which produces wetness in the body
dietary substance, which produces dryness in the body
dietary substance producing healthy effect in the body
dietary substance producing unhealthy effect in the body
diet, which has potential to become the part of body organ
dietary substance, which has potential to become the part of body organ after getting affected by the innate heat of body
dietary substance, which is ready to become part of body organ such as secondary fluid
dietary substance, which departs from its specific form and becomes the part of the body organ
substance, which is primarily used as diet but produces some pharmacological actions
dietary substance, which produces a effect in the body through its  specific form, matter  and quality
dietary substance, which produces effect in the body through its matter and specific form
dietary substance, which spontaneously gets absorbed in the organs without leaving behind considerable amount of residue in the stomach and vessels
dietary substance, which spontaneously does not get absorbed in the organs and a considerable amount of residue is left behind in the stomach and vessels
dietary substance, which is digested completely and does not remain immature
dietary substance, which is not digested completely
dietary substance, whose waste products get evacuated from the body quickly
dietary substance, whose waste products are not evacuated from the body in a quick manner
dietary substance, which does not stay in the stomach for a longer period of time
dietary substance, which stays in the stomach for a longer period of time
dietary substance, providing quality nourishment
dietary substance, providing little nourishment
dietary substance low in nutrition and produces more waste products
dietary substance, having more nutrition and producing less waste products
dietary substance producing humours of good quality in the body
dietary substance producing humours of bad quality in the body
diet, which produces blood of thin consistency in the body

Arabic_term: غذاء لطیف کثیر الغذاء حسن الکیموس
NUMC_TERM: Ghidhā’ Laṭīf Kathīr al-Ghidhā’ Ḥasan al-Kaymūs

NUMC_TERM: Ghidhā’ Laṭīf Qalīl al-Ghidhā’ Ḥasan al-Kaymūs

diets that increases the production of black bile
phlegm producing diets
sanguine producing diets
diets helping to gain body weight
diets causing flatulence
laxative diets
diets causing constipation
anti-flatulent diets
diets producing obstructions in the body
the water purified through boiling which does not cause flatulence and passes out of the body quickly
the water obtained through condensation of the vapours produced after boiling
the water attributed to be odourless, tasteless, free from contamination and  light in weight, it passes down from stomach quickly and can easily be rendered hot or cold
water that contains natural salts in appreciable amount and induces diarrhoea, makes skin thin and dry and causes emaciation
maintenance of optimal health by ensuring the supply of good quality air and measures adopted to minimise the effect of polluted air

NUMC_TERM: Ḥifẓ al-Ṣiḥḥa bi Ḥasabi’l Awqāt al-Arba‘a
Definition: application of regimens and modifications in daily  routine according to six essential factors and non-essential factors, e.g., exercise, purgation, venesection, emesis, etc., adopted to maintain the optimal health and to neutralize the non suitable  effects of seasonal changes and prevent from seasonal diseases

preservation of health by following the guidelines related to water intake, it includes timing of water intake, quantity and quality of water, avoiding water while taking food, during physical activity, bath, coitus and venesection, and drinking of water without thirst, etc.

preservation of health by following the guidelines related to food intake, it includes timing of food intake, quantity and quality of food, daily requirement of food, sequencing  of different kind of  food, consideration of health status of organs, different habitats and physical activity, etc.

NUMC_TERM: Ḥifẓ al-Ṣiḥḥa bi’l Nawm wa’l Yaqẓa
Definition: preservation of health by following the guidelines related to sleep and wakefulness, it includes moderate, timely and sound sleep, proper posture during sleep and avoidance from excess sleep and wakefulness and sleep on full stomach

preservation of health through exercise, which revives the innate heat, increases the subtle heat, disperses and expels the accumulated harmful material from body, hardens the organs and renders them fit for their functions, improves nutrition, removes the harmful substances from lungs and strengthens the physique
preservation of health through massage, which tones up the body, resolves the waste products, increases the innate heat, opens skin pores and relaxes the muscles
preservation of health through purgation, which evacuates the stagnated waste products and morbid humours from the body
preservation of health through emesis, which evacuates the waste products from the stomach and morbid humours from the upper part of the body

preservation of health through coitus, which produces exhilaration, increases positivity, subsides sorrow, grief and anger, increases the thinking capacity, rejuvenates innate heat of the body, resolves the waste products, and is useful for all melancholic disorders

preventive healthcare of  pregnant woman and the foetus through various regimes, e.g., intake of diets which produce blood of thin consistency and  humours of good quality, intake of fruit juices, gentle exercise, good sleep, use of fragrance, balance state of mind and avoidance of diets having diuretic properties, etc.
measures  of promotion of health of lactating women, e.g., dietary regimens, management of common problems associated with breastfeeding, exercise, massage, cleanliness, etc.
guidelines, which include preference to mother's milk, breastfeeding twice or thrice a day, giving little honey to baby before breastfeeding, cradle song, etc.
modalities for new-borns to keep them healthy which includes proper cutting of umbilical cord, treatment of skin of baby with salted water, keeping them in airy room and proper bathing, etc.
regimens, which include replacement of mother's milk with dietary substances, gentle exercise, application of oil on head and neck, rubbing of gums, taking care of hygiene of baby, etc.

regimens, including suitable dietary substances which produce humours of good quality, imbibing the qualities to control emotions; anger, fear, sorrow, etc., adoption of good habits, e.g., playing, massage,  light exercise, cleanliness and schooling, etc.

preservation of health through regimens, which include exercise, massage, evacuation of body from waste material according to season through venesection, purgation and intake of recommended dietary regimens

preservation of health during age of decline through regimens, which include cleansing of body from phlegm, intake of diet having hot and moist temperament, application of oil on body, avoiding heavy physical work, heavy exercise and black bile producing diets, etc.

preservation of health of elderly through regimens, which include intake of suitable diet and drinks, baths which render the body warm and moist, enough sleep,  moderate exercise and massage and application of oil, etc.

restoration of health of a person recovering from illness by strengthening innate heat and organs, gradual increase in dietary intake, mild exercise, application of oils producing moistness and avoidance from anger, heat, coitus, etc.

factors to be taken into account while selecting a place of residence, it include quality of soil, height, area covered with trees or exposed to sky, quality of water, quality of air, condition of neighbouring areas, quality of construction, ventilation, amount of light, temperature, climate, etc.
guidelines for travellers include precautionary measures to be taken into consideration while travelling

specific guidelines for land travellers which include special dietary regimens, recommendations about quality of water, practice of reduced sleep, long fasting, avoidance form heat, precautions against thirst, fatigue, sunstroke, frostbite,  etc.
specific guidelines for sea traveller which include special dietary regimens, measures to prevent sea sickness, management of vertigo, nausea, vomiting, etc.

use of turkish bath in routine life, which prevents the accumulation of morbid humours, resolves the waste products of the body, increases the innate heat and has the digestive, detergent, excretory effects, etc.
maintenance of health of organs by following certain guidelines and adopting specific measures and regimens

preservation of healthy status of hair through various measures which include application of oils to prevent hair fall, application of moisture producing oils to prevent the split, curling and breaking of hair; application of oils that promote hair growth, washing with suitable liquid preparations to remove dandruff and irritation; evacuation of predominant matters from brain and avoidance from phlegm producing things, etc.

preservation of healthy status of head through various measures which include habitual combing, cleansing of dirt and removal of lice by washing, avoiding the stuff  which causes production of gases, evacuation with suitable drugs, habitual emesis if there is the accumulation of phlegm in the stomach and inhalation of suitable fragrant materials

preservation of eyes through various measures which include local application of eye tonic antimony, washing of eyes by lukewarm purified water, evacuation of brain and avoidance from gas producing substances, salty and spicy diets, dust and smoke, staying in relatively hot temperature, inordinate sleep and wakefulness, excessive coitus, prolonged exposure to bright objects, eye strain, excessive crying, overeating, etc.
preservation of the health of nose through various measures which include cleansing of nostrils, drawing up the lukewarm water through nostrils and application of some suitable oil occasionally

preservation of the health of ear through various measures which include its cleansing, instilling few drops of bitter almond oil, hearing of pleasant sounds and avoidance from high pitched sound, extremely hot or cold temperature, dust and violent wind

preservation of healthy status of the tongue through various measures which include its repeated washing, rinsing with lukewarm water, intake of diets having sweet and fatty taste and avoidance from excessive talking and intake of distasteful foods, e.g., bitter, salty, spicy and sour items

preservation of healthy status of teeth through various measures which include avoidance from intake of sour diets, breaking of hard things with teeth, chewing of gummy materials, intake of hot things after cold things or vice versa and things which cause decay of teeth

Arabic_term: حفظ صحۃ الریۃ و قصبۃ الریۃ
NUMC_TERM: Ḥifẓ Ṣiḥḥa al-Ri’a wa Qaṣaba al-Ri’a
Definition: preservation of healthy status of lungs and trachea through various measures which include talking with moderate tone, expulsion of material coming to them from brain or lower part of body and application of some tonic or resolvent oils on chest
preservation of healthy status of heart through various measures including use of refrigerants and avoidance from distress and anxiety

preservation of healthy status of stomach through various measures, which include emesis on regular basis, use of suitable drug formulations, local application of fragrant tonic oils and keeping away from flatulent food and impure water
preservation of healthy status of intestine through avoidance from flatulent foodstuff
preservation of healthy status of liver through various measures which include use of deobstruent things, little use of sweets and avoiding physical activity and bathing after taking the food

preservation of healthy status of organs of urinary system through various measures which include use of diuretic substances on regular interval, cleansing of urinary tract, emesis and avoidance from the intake of impure water
preservation of healthy status of joints through various measures including emesis, purgation, moderate movement and local application of oil occasionally
voluntary prevention of conception
measures adopted to prevent conception  which include use of oral contraceptive drugs, local use of drugs and measures etc.
